subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] The principles of my dictionary
msgSnippet: ... [BPJ wrote] ... The problem is not to merge mentally when reading, but that they have to *un-merge* mentally when *writing*, by associating certain TO
messageBody:
Moira O'Brien skrev:
> On 07/12/2007, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:
>
[BPJ wrote]
>>> The reason for not distinguishing THOUGHT from LOT is
>>> mainly that
>
>> My dictionary makes the distinction between THOUGHT and
>> LOT. If we decide on your spelling reform, it is very
>> easy to merge THOUGHT and LOT later (I think).
>
> I am against most of these mergers for practical reasons.
> I have no difficulty in reading On for Awe when I know
> that the writer from the USand in all cases, being from
> England, I don't merge any of these vowel sounds in speech
> so merging them in text would be retrograde. I do however
> see the problem for the US English speakers and can only
> suggest that they do the mergers mentally.

The problem is not to merge mentally when reading, but that
they have to *un-merge* mentally when *writing*, by
associating certain TO spellings with {O} (Awe) and {A} (Ah)
rather than {Q} (Ox), and it is hard to this sucessfully
without looking up all words where their /A/ corresponds to
a spelling containing any of _a u w_ in a pronunciation
dictionary giving British pronunciations, such as the EPD or
LPD. Clearly it is unpractical and absurd to demand that
everyone keep looking up words containing /A/, /O/ or /Q/ in
dictionaries even if it mustn't mean that they acquire
expensive pronunciation dictionaries from overseas. Thus any
standardization of QS spelling has to be based on rules that
can be stated on the formula

- Write phoneme X as with QS letter Y except when it
corresponds to TO grapheme Z.

The problem is the same with the lexical set BATH, which
belongs with FATHER (/A/) in British but with TRAP (/a/) in
American. It is quite impossible to give any exceptionless
rule in terms of TO spellings for when TO _a_ corresponds to
British /A/ and when to /a/, but it will not be very hard
for speakers of Southern British accents to mentally
distinguish TRAP and FATHER when reading, because the
functional load of the distinction is very low. Besides many
speakers in the North of England, Scotland and Northern
Ireland actually lack the distinction.

(For the concept of 'functional load' see

<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functional_load>)

The lexical sets LOT (British /Q/) and THOUGHT (British /O/)
are especially troublesome because the lexical set CLOTH,
parallel to BATH, which goes with LOT in British but with
THOUGHT Eastern US accents, and all three fall together with
FATHER /A/ for most Western American speakers. It would be
extremely hard for Western American speakers (who are the
majority both within the US and in the English-speaking
world as a whole) to both learn the rules for which QS
letter corresponds to which TO spelling, plus a largish list
of exceptions to this rule -- mainly words where TO _au, aw,
ou(gh), ow_ correspond to British /Q/ rather than the
expected /O/. Additionally there is even within Southern
British accents a set of words which vary between /Q/ and
/O/, mainly _salt_ and other words with TO _al_. Indeed TO
_al_ is problematical even if one merges LOT-THOUGHT-CLOTH
and TRAP-FATHER-BATH respectively, since these words would
still fall into, and vacillate between, the two sets.

Rather than require that everyone learns complicated
rules, *and* list of exceptions one can give American and
British writers each three simple rules of exception from
phonemic spelling:

* For American writers:
1. Write /A/ with {Q}, except where TO spells it with
_a_ not followed by _ u_ or _w_, where it should be
written {a}.
2. If you have /O/ not followed by /r/ write it with {Q}
in those cases.
3. Write /y/ not followed by /r/ as {I} when it
corresponds to _i_.

* For British writers:
1. Write both /A/ and /a/ with {a} except before _r_.
2. Write both /O/ and /Q/ as {Q} when no _r_ follows.
3. Write /Q/ as {O} when followed by _r_.

As you see the Americans will still have to put up with the
most complicated rules -- comparable to the complication
for the British of writing silent {r}, since added
distinctions are harder to learn than mergers --, and I
think the British must have to put up with some
'retrograde' mergers here in the interest of getting a
manageable common spelling norm, where people can map their
own pronunciation to TO spellings without having to
memorize lists of exceptions. It's not ideal, but it avoids
putting all the burden of learning exceptions and
complicated rules on one side of the accent divide.

My dictionary will still try to note actual pronunciations
and pronunciatio n variants in parentheses, writing e.g.:

- _call_ kQl (O/A)
- _father_ faDyr (A)
- _origin_ OrIJIn (Q, y, y)

so you can still see the expected pronunciations in the
dictionary. N.B. that there actually are minorities who say
[faDy(r)], that American /kOl/ where it occurs is
phonetically [kQl], and that [OryJyn] actually is the
majority pronunciation!

I neither can nor will 'outlaw' phonetic 'local' spellings,
my intention is to suggest a common denominator for those
who *want* an internationally common spelling. N.B. not a
*least* common denominator -- which would be really
retrograde, so that we might as well leave out vowels
entirely -- but a compromise which hopefully can be accepted
on both sides of the Atlantic. Clearly I also have the
interests of ESL users in mind, since these can be expected
to want a standard spelling which works about equally well
with both major pronunciation models.

/BP 8^)>
